sub_topic: Calculation of entropy change for a chemical reaction
message_1: Determine the entropy change for the combustion of methane gas (CH4) at constant pressure and 298 K. Given the standard molar entropy values are: S°(CH4) = 186 J/mol.K, S°(O2) = 205 J/mol.K, S°(CO2) = 214 J/mol.K and S°(H2O) = 188 J/mol.K.
message_2:
To determine the entropy change for the combustion of methane gas, we first need to write the balanced chemical equation for the combustion reaction:

CH₄(g) + 2O₂(g) → CO₂(g) + 2H₂O(g)

Now, we can calculate the entropy change (ΔS) using the standard molar entropy values provided:

ΔS = ΣS°(products) - ΣS°(reactants)

ΔS = [1 mol CO₂ × S°(CO₂) + 2 mol H₂O × S°(H₂O)] - [1 mol CH₄ × S°(CH₄) + 2 mol O₂ × S°(O₂)]

ΔS = [1 mol × 214 J/mol.K + 2 mol × 188 J/mol.K] - [1 mol × 186 J/mol.K + 2 mol × 205 J/mol.K]

ΔS = [214 J + 376 J] - [186 J + 410 J]

ΔS = 590 J - 596 J

ΔS = -6 J/mol.K

The entropy change for the combustion of methane gas at constant pressure and 298 K is -6 J/mol.K.
